text:
Thank you for having
the opportunity to share a bit about the
work that we do at ETH. And yeah, let's dive
right into this.

I will talk a bit about
how we are thinking at the moment about robot
morphologies, how we want

to build robots of the
future, and how we could maybe rethink some of
the assumptions we have made in the past
about robotic designs,

about robotic control. But to start, let me take
this quote from Joanna.
Joanna is a novelist. She enjoys writing books.

She's not an engineer. She's not a scientist. And what she said
is, you know what's

the biggest problem with
pushing all things AI? Wrong direction. I want AI to do my laundry
and dishes so that I

can do the art and writing. I don't want I to do
my art and writing so that I have to do the
laundry and the dishes.

And I think she has
something to say here, which is quite relevant. So we can, obviously, use
ChatGPT and other tools

these days to really
make our life easier when it comes to writing
these manuscripts or emails.

But like pushing the limit
of what our robots can do, I think there's lots of
open space to work in this.

So what do robots
already do for us today? Where do they help us in
terms of home and at work?
What comes to your mind? Toasters. Toasters? Oh, that's an interesting robot.

This is the first. I've not heard this one before. OK. I'm not sure how much
autonomy is in the toaster.

The otology of toast. The ontology of toast, OK. Any other robots that
you can think of?

Roomba. Roomba, vacuums, yeah. I mean, obviously,
this is a robot. This is the robot that we know.

It's going to weld your other
cars and autonomous vehicles. But there's the Roomba
or these vacuum cleaners

or these the robots that
will wipe your floor. And then there's
also these creatures.

I think you call
that one Clifford, I learned today,
because it's red

and it's like a
robot dog, Clifford. It's actually-- for us, it's
our home robot from Zurich.

It's the animal. But one thing they don't
do is they do interactions

with the world. They don't really do that yet. I mean, they may be
vacuuming and they touch the floor or
something, or they maybe

make a perfectly valid line. But the more messy things, for
example, handling bakery items

or doing surgery or even, yeah,
doing the fulfillment center

duties that currently an army
of labor workers are doing, all of these things
require interactions, even

restocking our shelves
in supermarkets. So the question is, why is it
so hard for this embodied AI

that Joanna wants to
see, why is it so hard for them to interact
with the world?

Well, there's already
people going doing this. You might have seen Boston
Dynamics picking up plates

from a cart, taking
it from one side to another to help
in the assembly line.

Figure AI does something
like this, too. They're trying to do
the dishes for Joanna.

In this case, it's
just a mock setup. And there's billions, today I
learned this, about $50 billion

going into this space for
AI, for object manipulation. And I'm thinking, if the robot
would do this in my kitchen,

I wouldn't want to
stand next to it. So it is a bit scary to think
about the current technologies

we use, the metal machinery,
the motors, and all of this coming into the design. It's going to actually
be quite painful.

So is this design ready to
safely interact with us? Not really.

So we need to rethink
the robot's morphology. And one way you can
think about this

is we could bring together the
ideas from multiple worlds. So we could look at soft robots.

Soft robots is something
I've looked at a lot so far in my past
into, which is just

to build robots to make them
soft for the sake of softness. I remember many years ago,
sitting in a car with Oussama,

Oussama Khatib
here from Stanford. And he was asking
me, Robert, why are you building soft robots?

What's the point of them? They can't really do anything
like they're so soft. And I mean, I think
there is something

to be said about they can
maybe not handle high payloads, but they do have
something to say. If they interact with you,
they're not going to hurt you.

Steve was also telling me
today the soft grippers that could be on the end
effector of a robot, they can actually, at least
for that, realm of the robot

when it touches you
and hits you, not really caused as much
damage as a rigid gripper. But then they can't do
the payload capacity

of a rigid robot. A rigid robot can
actually lift weights. It can move over rough terrain,
and it can be quite sturdy.
And then there is nature. Nature, that's us. That's the animals. That's what we have in nature.

It's a musculoskeletal design. So what can we do to bring
together the insights

from all of these
worlds to build these hybrid robots,
these robots that have an inspiration from the
musculoskeletal design idea,

but also from
taking the softness of the soft robotic world
to build these muscles

and other soft tissues. And in the end, to have a robot
that can both carry payloads but also can be gentle and can
be adapted to the environment.

So it's mechanical impedance
can be better matched with the actual worlds. Yesterday, for example, I
saw a Booster Robotics robot.

I think you also have one here. I saw it earlier in the sensor. When you turn it on and have it
walk around, it's really loud.

It's hitting the floor
and stomping around. And it's just because
there's many, many things he can do with a
musculoskeletal scale design

that rigid robots with
its motors can do. So today I will be talking about
a couple of ideas in this space.

So first, I want to talk about
the most extreme ends of what we're looking into, which
is to actually build muscles

from cells. And then I will talk about what
are the challenges that we face

there, and even
quickly mention what could be even medical
implications of learning

about tissue engineering
with biological cells that help for robotics, but
maybe also beyond this.

And then I will talk about
musculoskeletal designs. So taking it not
just from one muscle,

but thinking about many muscles
and what are the challenges there, towards
making them actually

more feasible and untethered,
towards the question of how can we produce all of it, not
just the muscles, but also

the whole structure. And then what are the
autonomy challenges there? How can I actually
showcase these designs

that I can do
something autonomously? Because if I just
build something, show it a great design,
but it doesn't do anything,

you won't necessarily
give up that [INAUDIBLE] robots that you're already
having in your lap.

So what can we take
inspiration from? Obviously, I can take my hands.

I can take an arm. I can take a leg. I can look at the human anatomy. And I can ask myself, what
are the key elements that

make it function and work? It's the muscle. The muscle moves at all. The muscle makes the key
ingredient, in my opinion,

of a robot. If I don't have an actuator,
in this case a muscle, it's not really a robot. But then I also
need other parts.

I need the bones, I need the
tendons, and I need the joints, and I need the ligaments. So we need to come up with
solutions for all of this

and the interplay of all of
this to build our future robots. We have started to
look a lot into muscles

because we see the biggest lack
in the musculoskeletal area is we don't have good muscles
to build these robots from.

So let me spend a lot
of time on this today. So the first thing, as
I mentioned already,

is we have a part of our group
that just asked the question,

can we build robots
that are made of cells? So can we build muscles
that actually use cell?

And this is not your
hypothetical cell on the computer
that you simulate. No, I'm talking here about
using the cell from animals.

And now the question is, why? Why would I want
to go this route?
Why would I want to use cells? [LAUGHTER]

Isn't crazy that we
can speak, walk, run, bicycle by eating two
hamburgers of food a day?

The way we process energy
and move is really efficient. Yes. So the way that
we take in energy

is drastically different to the
humanoids that we see right now. They have to have a
battery, but the cells, we

take our hamburgers bogus or
maybe other healthier foods. But, yes, definitely. So if I were to look at a few
points that people would say,

these are the features
that we want to really make use of when we work
with cells, then

it is the self-repair,
the ability for cells, for many cells to
come together and eventually,

in a swarm arrangement, to
assemble, to self-repair, to be self-sensing.

So cells have
multiple capabilities. They're not just for
example, a muscle, but they can also
have proprioception.

And they also inherently soft. So it meets the requirement
that as a soft robot, as I like to see, cells
can be soft if they are not

becoming a bone. And they can also be
sustainable and eco-compliant. So I'm using organic material
that goes into the machinery

and it produces the structure. I don't need to necessarily, if
I find fully sustainable ways,

produce a lot of waste
with these robots. So when we look at this,
how should we go about this?

So basically, we
look at a muscle. And a muscle consists of all
of these individual myoblasts

that you start off with. And you could culture
them in a Petri dish. And well, this doesn't really
give you a muscle yet if I just

throw them randomly in there. So you have to come up
with ways of bringing them into a structure that
it can be a muscle.

So one way of doing it
is you take a hydrogel and you throw so-called
stem or progenitor

cells into the hydrogel. And with the right
differentiation protocols

applied to it and
maturation protocols, you can actually build
up muscle fibers.

So in the interest of
time, let me dive directly into my favorite project
that we're doing right now.

And this is work that one of
the PhD students in my group is doing. Her name is Aiste.

And she has been
looking into, how can we make a combination
of these muscles with a structure that
can actually be a robot?

So what she does is she
basically creates scaffolds. And these scaffolds are made
with a printing technique called

xolography. You see the scaffold
up there on the left. It's basically a long
rectangular structure

with lots of small grooves on
the order of 100 micrometers. And this structure allows, when
we place the cells on top of it,

a mix of slurry-- I will get to it in a moment-- to align along those
grooves, and also to restructure this whole
scaffold, and, eventually,

makes a swimmer out of this. So we have this construct
and we have a printer that uses two wavelengths.

These two wavelengths
go into a bath. And wherever two wavelengths
hit, it takes a photoinitiator.

That photoinitiator becomes
active because of the two wavelengths. At that point, it causes a
polymerization of the hydrogel.

So we use this to
build these scaffolds. And then we put
the cells on top. And I can tell you
right now, we are also

working on projects where
we not put them on top, but we directly
put them in there. But this will be for the future.

But for now, let
me talk about this. So we have basically
the scaffold. We have the cells. And then in the end,
we get the scaffold

with the cells seated on top. And we start at day zero. Down there, you
see the construct.

It has the scaffold underneath. It has the cells on top. And then as the procedure in
the differentiation goes along

and the matrix gets remodeled,
the matrix starts to shrink. And so the whole thing starts
to bend into this U-shaped form.

That's because these
muscles, they start to fuse, they start to come together. And as the days pass
by, we eventually

end up with this construct
that is really bends into shape and the muscle has
matured, and now we

can start playing
around with it. So we're going from myoblasts
towards these myofibers.

When you get it wrong,
that's what you get. So if you get a too soft of an
underlying scaffold that is not

surviving, we would say,
it has a poor survival of the maturation
process, you end up with these slightly
dysfunctional swimmers.

If you get the mix
right for the scaffold, you can actually get a pretty
good proper swimming behavior from it.

And it swims-- I will
get to this in a moment-- because of we give
it a stimulus that causes the muscle to contract,
and we can paste that stimulus.

We can control it. So Aiste went ahead and she
tried different frequencies. She wanted to see what happens
if I go at different frequencies

with this construct. So if I go at 1 Hertz,
what ends up happening is we have these slow swimmers
that can travel a short distance

in a longer time. As I go up in frequency, you
get more faster swimming

behavior in the Petri dish. And here this is going up
to 3 Hertz and then 4 Hertz.

And then eventually, I
greedily go up to 5 Hertz. And it gets slower.

It's still a bit
faster than 4 Hertz. It swims out of
the frame faster, so that's why the
line is shorter.

And now the question to you,
if I greedily go up to a higher frequency, what happens?
Slower. Why?
Maybe viscocity or something. Friction, I'm not sure, though. Viscosity and friction, OK.

Any other guesses? Yeah. I'm thinking it might paralyze
because the stimulation is
too high. Yes, yes. It cramps. It kind of goes into tetanus.

So that's what we get here. This little one that's
just like, ah, sorry, I can't do this anymore.

You're overstimulating me. This is too much. I can't handle this. So, yes, it does
not anymore swim.

It's interesting. So you can start learning
about these muscle constructs and how they behave
without actually

having to harm an animal. So I want to just mention
here, we actually never killed an animal for this experiment.

We just got a cell line
from a supplier that has immortalized the cell line.

And we can just passage it and
multiply more and more of these and use it for this experiment. So this is a close up
from the 5 Hertz swimmer.

So over there, you
see the electrodes that gives an electrostatic
field at 5 Hertz.

Every 1 over 5 seconds,
we give a 1% stimulus. And that means for that 1%,
it will get a short stimulus,

a 1% duty cycle, and then it
will start its contraction, and then it will
eventually relax again.

And then the next one comes. And so this is what happens
here with the swimming. Yes. What happens when we increase
the amplitude [INAUDIBLE]

Well, it doesn't really-- it doesn't-- at some point, you
start electrocuting the cells in some way.

But we haven't gone
too high with this. It's just a trigger. The energy comes
from the nutrients.

It doesn't come from
the electrical field. So when we look at
this swimmer, we compared it to other biohybrid
ideas and directions.

And we found, we got a
much higher body length per minute swimming
speed with this design.

And so now we're investigating
this area even further. And we're trying to
understand, for example, can we model the behavior here?

Can we understand why
does it swim this? Can we understand the swimming
behavior, the interactions

of the surrounding
fluid with the construct and why it actually swims? Can we also do optimization
of these structures

by changing the
length of the muscle relative to the length
of the scaffolds, and allow us to study why--

if this model is actually
accurate compared to an experiment that we built? And so this is all
work in progress.

And it becomes a nice
playground for us to learn about these
biohybrid systems. Another problem is perfusion.

Perfusion means, how
can we actually make this muscle be thicker
and thicker and bigger?

Because in the
end, we don't want to just have a couple of hundred
of micrometers of a muscle,

but we want to have really
centimeter thick muscle or more. And so what we're
doing here is we

want to understand what
happens when we put in channels into the structure.

Because if you don't
put channels in there, you will have dying cells in the
core of your muscle construct.

All of our muscles have
a perfusion system, and this allows our muscles
to actually take away

waste products and carry oxygen
and nutrients to your muscle. And so the same
thing we do here.

So if I look into a muscle
construct that has no perfusion channels, what we
will see is that we

have maybe 150
micrometers of somewhat built up myotubes, which is
going to give you contractions.

And the deeper I go
into the construct, up here, these are
all dead cells. And this is bad. I don't just want to greedily
build a big construct.

If it actually doesn't get
nutrients, it will not survive, and it won't give me power and
won't give me muscle power.

So Miriam started
looking into this. And she's like,
hey, let's actually make a construct that we
extrude both the myoblasts,

but also an anchor
structure on each side. And then we also interlace
perfusion channels that

can also afterwards be removed. And with this experiment,
we basically take a muscle.

We run a dye through it. And we want to see how quickly
does this muscle become pinkish, like becoming this color.

So we take constructs
with channels and without channels and
just naturally gravity driven perfusion already.

We just take the construct
laid at an angle, place our nutrients with a dye,
the nutrient solution on top.

And we see we get-- within a minute or so,
we get our perfusion through the construct,
which we wouldn't

get without the channels. And another thing we see in
this study is, so six days

into the maturation
process, we still don't have fully
built-up muscle fibers, and we still have
these wide channels

that we produced initially. But as it further
matures, these channels get thinner and thinner.

So that's because of the
shrinking and the remodeling that the cells are doing
to the hydrogel matrix.

So that's not even accounted
for in these models that we just showed you. We haven't really accounted
for the maturation process that

goes from an initial design
to a matured muscle that has completely reshaped itself.

So we're still a
long way from using these actuators to build this.

I mean, you see, there's lots
of muscles in a human leg. And I mean, they're really big.

The thing I just
showed to you here, this is on the order of 1
to 2 centimeters in size.

And we want to build muscles
that are much larger than this. So one thing that we
have been looking into

is using hydraulically amplified
self-healing electrostatic actuators, which is
kind of a mouthful,

also just simply called HASELs. And this is something that
Christoph Keplinger's group at UC Boulder, when he was
still at UC Boulder, developed.

And we've been using
this as a starting point for musculoskeletal
designs that are

taking electrical
energy from a battery and directly placing
it into contractional.

We want to go away from
this principle of taking electrical energy into
an electromagnetic motor,

into a pump, then flowing
liquids into a structure. We believe this is way less
efficient and more bulky.

So this principle here
basically takes these pouches that you see on the left. And then when you apply
charges onto these electrodes,

they act like a capacitor that
is soft, that will zip together, and it will cause the
whole construct to shorten.

And that's your
muscle basically. The muscle now
lifts the weight up. So this is how it
looks like in real.

This is using two
dielectric films.

And then we place
on it a carbon-- we put a little bit of
carbon electrode material

on the outside. And then we put opposite
charges on each side. And as I then apply a voltage,
it lifts up a weight over there.

So the first thing we tried
with this is we made a fish. And that's always a
nice thing to start off

with because we don't have
to worry about gravity. We can just throw it into the
liquid and we can try it out.

But we had a few
problems with this here. So one thing that
you can quite see is we are not swimming in water.
Let me ask you why. It's conductive. It's conductive. And why is this a problem?

[INAUDIBLE] Yeah. So the electrodes in the
original HASEL design,

they're just exposed. And you don't really want them
to be in a conductive liquid. So we started swimming in oil.

But swimming in oil
is actually quite bad. It's not so easy to swim in
oil as compared to water. Have you ever tried
to swim in oil?

Probably better this
way, not to swim in oil. So this fish had to swim in oil.

And it also had multiple
electrodes that come in here. And so that lets me point
to the elephant in the room.

The elephant in the room is
this humongous power supplies that sit on the outside.

And people usually don't like
to show them because they're not very attractive to
talk about robots

that will discover the world,
but there's this huge power supply. So we then started going.

First, we tried to
think outside of water to see, can we use the
HASEL design to build legs,

towards the idea of a
musculoskeletal design? So here this is our
baseline system.

We call it a joint-centered
system, a joint-centered design, where we take an
electromagnetic motor and we place it into each joint.

And then we
basically run current through these
electromagnetic motor units.

It's a brushless motor. And then it moves around. This is what we know from
the current humanoids. And we built
everything the same way

as we built, in the
second, our HASEL system. So here, we have the motor. We have an encoder in there.

So we can also know where we
are in terms of positioning. And we need this. Otherwise, it doesn't work. And then we build a
musculoskeletal system.

Here, we ditch the motor. The rest of the carbon fiber
structure remains the same.

And then we place a ton of
muscles, HASEL muscles in there that basically now become our
antagonist muscle units, that

allow our leg to be pulling
antagonistically with a lever arm onto our structure.

And so this is the
Hazel on the right side. We call it self-sensing
because essentially, it

allows us to sense
the contraction and also to sense the change
of capacitance under loading.

And so basically, the way
you can think about this, on the left side, we have
the electromagnetic motors.

And on the right side, we
have the HASEL muscles. These are our actuators. Then we have on
the left side, we

would use usually just
joint angle encoders. And the right side, we can make
do with just the self-sensing

capacity-- the self-sensing capability
of the capacitors. And then finally,
on the left side,

you usually would have
a linear transmission that could be a planetary
gearbox or some other way of taking the high rotations
per minute and the lower torque

to translate it up to a
higher torque and a lower rotations per minute,
which you need often for robotic applications.

And we don't need this. We just use different nonlinear
moment arms for our tendons to attach to, the same way that
we do it in our human body.

Or maybe Mother Nature
does it in our human body. So this is the
play system, and it

has the hip flexor, the hip
extensor, the knee extensor, and the knee flexor. So we have these two degrees
of freedom in the system.

Then we have four high
voltage amplifier units. And we also do packaging
of these muscles.

And the way you can think
about the design rule for this is if you stack
the pouches in series,

you get more strain,
more delta X. If you put more on top of each
other, you get more force.

This is how you can
basically design your muscle unit in this case.

So when you flex the hip,
it moves the tip down in the yellow line. And then you flex and
you extend the knee,

it moves it further,
and so forth. So we go through the full
motion cycle with the tip. And now let's get
to some experiments.

So Thomas then started
working together with Tashi on how agile is a system, how
adaptive, also how efficient,

and how a self-sensing
work for the system. So when we look
at agility, we try

to do, for example,
high jump experiments. We'll just see, can this thing
actually hop off the ground? And how does it
hop off the ground?

And how are the impact
forces once they lift off and land again? So this led us already study the
system from that perspective.

And then we also looked into how
fast can I actually run this? So I can accelerate
this at 0.5 Hertz,

and I get a certain
motion cycle. And I can go faster here. So I can, for example, go to
3 Hertz and I get a fairly--

this is a slow speed. I get 3 Hertz, I get a
fairly large motion cycle. But as I go up in
speed from 3 Hertz,

I will eventually see
I can go even faster. And I will get a
smaller motion cycle. So 5 Hertz already, you see
the motion range goes down.

And we can run this all
the way up to 10 Hertz. So it's actually quite agile. Actually, let me run this again.

So this is 10 Hertz. So the thing can
be run quite fast just by charging and
discharging the muscle.

But we get a fairly
small motion range. And I get to this
in a moment what causes a limitation
to the motion range

when you have two muscles
pull onto the structure. So, now, we tried an
open loop experiment

where we put it onto a boom. And now, the leg is
hopping our little garden. So, this is like the
lab garden environment

with a cactus that's
probably the only-- and a proper plant.

That's probably the plants you
can easily maintain in the lab. And you see the leg is
actually capable of going

over different type
of terrain, not using any closed-loop control.

All we're doing is we
changing the signal that you see on the top between
the actuation of the leg extensor and the leg flexor.

And that allows it to hop
over it with a hopping gait and go over the terrain. And we can also try this
obviously with other surfaces

and see how well it
hops on these surfaces. And we can also try
different hopping modes. So, here is the speed mode where
we can do a very long stride.

But we can also do
the efficiency mode where we use less energy.

So, it's overall from
the cost of transport, the more efficient mode. And then there's also this one.

That's like the crawler that's
actually the most efficient mode because I don't have to take
off, I just scroll forward.

But it only works because I take
the rubber tip off the foot. So, I have a little bit
of better grip going down

on the surface. And I don't have
a rough terrain. So, then we looked at
the cost of transport.

At the cost of
transport, we found we were quite good, at
least for the system that we looked at in terms of a single
foot compared to land animals.

And then here we
looked at the heating. So on the left side is the
motor that we compare to. And the right side
is the muscle.

And the motor heats
up quite a bit because we constantly run
currents to hold the payloads.

And on the right side,
it does not require this. So, this allowed us to do
investigations into efficiency

as well. And then there's another
thing where we looked into the self-sensing muscle. So, we wanted to
understand, can we

actually use the capacitive
change of the muscle to detect an obstacle?

So, here's the obstacle
on the left side. That's just a stone. And now, the robot
is just hopping

in a gate, a normal gate. And then it hits
against the stone. It senses a change
in its capacitance,

and it changes its gait cycle. So, here you see the
capacitance change.

So, the moment it makes contact,
we get a different capacitance profile for hitting
against the stone.

And then we just change to a
different controller that lets this leg hop over the stone.

Then we also looked into what
if we not only use the muscle by itself with its capacitor.

Nothing speaks against
still to use an encoder. Like why not? Why not have an encoder
in the joints as well?

So, then we try to see, can we
track different motion cycles? Can we do a circle?

Could we do a figure 8
and difference of motions? And how accurately could we
track a reference trajectory

with the tip. And one thing we found
in this experiment, so we were able to track it. But we had a fairly
limited motion range.

Now, the question
to you is, why? Why is in the setup that I just
showed you with this play leg?

What's the challenge in
terms of motion range? Why is the motion
range that you see here

limited to a small motion
range in the tip of the leg? It's not able to do
these large motions.

I can do this with my arm. I can do quite large motions
with the tip of my finger. So.

What is mechanically
the challenge here? The muscle. The muscle. And what's the problem
with the muscle?

Why can I not do this? It's a single
isotropic material. So it can contract or extend
as far as much as possible.

So, except it cannot contract. But particularly, it cannot
extend as far as our muscle can.

So, it can contract. It can actually technically,
it can collapse this muscle passively.

It can collapse it because it
will just fold up or buckle up. But the problem comes and
you see this now here.

If I take the muscle and I
pull on it, it doesn't extend. It's a film. It's a flexible film, but it's
not a really extensible film.
